Indic[a]
c. 800 million (2018)[1]–1.5 billion[2]
Linguistic classification

The Indo-Aryan languages (or sometimes simply Indic languages[a]) are a branch of the Indo-Iranian languages in the Indo-European language family. As of the early 21st century
column2: they have more than 800 million speakers
column3: primarily concentrated east of the Indus river in Bangladesh
column7: Maldives and Nepal.[1] Moreover
column8: apart from the Indian subcontinent
column9: large immigrant and expatriate Indo-Aryan–speaking communities live in Northwestern Europe
column15: along with several million speakers of Romani languages primarily concentrated in Southeastern Europe. There are over 200 known Indo-Aryan languages.[5]

column1: Modern Indo-Aryan languages descend from Old Indo-Aryan languages such as early Vedic Sanskrit
column2: through Middle Indo-Aryan languages (or Prakrits).[6][7][8][9] The largest such languages in terms of first-speakers are Hindi–Urdu (c. 330 million)
column3: [10] Bengali (242 million)
column4: [11] Punjabi (about 150 million)
column5: [12][13] Marathi (112 million)
column6: and Gujarati (60 million). A 2005 estimate placed the total number of native speakers of the Indo-Aryan languages at nearly 900 million people.[14] Other estimates are higher suggesting a figure of 1.5 billion speakers of Indo-Aryan languages.[2]

column1:
Theories

[edit]
Classification tree of the Indo-Aryan languages
The Indo-Aryan family as a whole is thought to represent a dialect continuum
column2: where languages are often transitional towards neighboring varieties.[15] Because of this
column3: the division into languages vs. dialects is in many cases somewhat arbitrary. The classification of the Indo-Aryan languages is controversial
column4: with many transitional areas that are assigned to different branches depending on classification.[16] There are concerns that a tree model is insufficient for explaining the development of New Indo-Aryan
column5: with some scholars suggesting the wave model.[17]

column1:
Subgroups

[edit]
The following table of proposals is expanded from Masica (1991) (from Hoernlé to Turner)
column2: and also includes subsequent classification proposals. The table lists only some modern Indo-Aryan languages.

column1: Ethnologue (2020)[18]
Glottolog (2024)[19]
Anton I. Kogan
column3: conducted a lexicostatistical study of the New Indo-Aryan languages based on a 100-word Swadesh list
column4: using techniques developed by the glottochronologist and comparative linguist Sergei Starostin.[17] That grouping system is notable for Kogan's exclusion of Dardic from Indo-Aryan on the basis of his previous studies showing low lexical similarity to Indo-Aryan (43.5%) and negligible difference with similarity to Iranian (39.3%).[20] He also calculated Sinhala–Dhivehi to be the most divergent Indo-Aryan branch. Nevertheless
column5: the modern consensus of Indo-Aryan linguists tends towards the inclusion of Dardic based on morphological and grammatical features.[citation needed]

column1:
Inner–Outer hypothesis

[edit]
The Inner–Outer hypothesis argues for a core and periphery of Indo-Aryan languages
column2: with Outer Indo-Aryan (generally including Eastern and Southern Indo-Aryan
column4: Dardic and Pahari) representing an older stratum of Old Indo-Aryan that has been mixed to varying degrees with the newer stratum that is Inner Indo-Aryan. It is a contentious proposal with a long history
column5: with varying degrees of claimed phonological and morphological evidence. Since its proposal by Rudolf Hoernlé in 1880 and refinement by George Grierson it has undergone numerous revisions and a great deal of debate
column6: with the most recent iteration by Franklin Southworth and Claus Peter Zoller based on robust linguistic evidence (particularly an Outer past tense in -l-). Some of the theory's skeptics include Suniti Kumar Chatterji and Colin P. Masica.[citation needed]

column1:
Groups

[edit]
Percentage of Indo-Aryan speakers by native language:
Hindustani (including Hindi and Urdu) (25.4%)
Bengali (20.7%)
Punjabi (9.4%)
Marathi (5.6%)
Gujarati (3.8%)
Bhojpuri (3.1%)
Maithili (2.6%)
Odia (2.5%)
Sindhi (1.9%)

Dardic

[edit]
Main article: Dardic languages

The Dardic languages (also Dardu or Pisaca) are a group of Indo-Aryan languages largely spoken in the northwestern extremities of the Indian subcontinent. Dardic was first formulated by George Abraham Grierson in his Linguistic Survey of India but he did not consider it to be a subfamily of Indo-Aryan. The Dardic group as a genetic grouping (rather than areal) has been scrutinised and questioned to a degree by recent scholarship: Southworth
column3: says "the viability of Dardic as a genuine subgroup of Indo-Aryan is doubtful" and "the similarities among [Dardic languages] may result from subsequent convergence".[21]: 149

column1: The Dardic languages are thought to be transitional with Punjabi and Pahari (e.g. Zoller describes Kashmiri as "an interlink between Dardic and West Pahāṛī")
column2: [22]: 83  as well as non-Indo-Aryan Nuristani; and are renowned for their relatively conservative features in the context of Proto-Indo-Aryan.

column4: Indus Kohistani

column1:
Northern Zone

[edit]
Main article: Northern Indo-Aryan languages

column3: are spoken throughout the Himalayan regions of the subcontinent.

column1: • Western Pahari: Dogri
column11: Mahasu Pahari

column1:
Northwestern Zone

[edit]
Northwestern Indo-Aryan languages are spoken in the northwestern region of India and eastern region of Pakistan. Punjabi is spoken predominantly in the Punjab region and is the official language of
column3: India">the northern Indian state of Punjab
column4: in addition to being the most widely-spoken language in Pakistan. Sindhi and its variants are spoken natively in the Pakistani province of Sindh and neighbouring regions. Northwestern languages are ultimately thought to be descended from Shauraseni Prakrit
column5: with influence from Persian and Arabic.[23]

column1: • Central: Majhi
• Western: Hindko (Kohati
column8: Saraiki (Riasti

column1: • Sindhi: Sindhi

Western Zone

[edit]
Western Indo-Aryan languages are spoken in central and western India
column2: in states such as Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan
column3: in addition to contiguous regions in Pakistan. Gujarati is the official language of Gujarat
column4: and is spoken by over 50 million people. In Europe
column5: various Romani languages are spoken by the Romani people
column6: an itinerant community who historically migrated from India. The Western Indo-Aryan languages are thought to have diverged from their northwestern counterparts
column7: although they have a common antecedent in Shauraseni Prakrit.

column1: • Rajasthani: Bagri
• Gujarati: Gujarati
• Bhil: Kalto
• Romani: Carpathian Romani
Central Zone[edit]
Main article: Central Indo-Aryan languages

column2: Central Indo-Aryan languages are spoken primarily in the western Gangetic plains
column3: including Delhi and parts of the Central Highlands
column4: where they are often transitional with neighbouring lects. Many of these languages
column5: including Braj and Awadhi
column6: have rich literary and poetic traditions. Urdu
column7: a Persianised derivative of Dehlavi descended from Shauraseni Prakrit
column8: is the official language of Pakistan and also has strong historical connections to India
column9: where it also has been designated with official status. Hindi
column10: a standardised and Sanskritised register of Dehlavi
column11: is the official language of the Government of India (along with English). Together with Urdu
column12: it is the third most-spoken language in the world.

column1: • Western Hindi: Hindustani (including Standard Hindi and Standard Urdu)
• Eastern Hindi: Bagheli
column4: Awadhi (Fiji Hindi

column1:
Eastern Zone

[edit]
Main article: Eastern Indo-Aryan languages

column3: are spoken throughout the eastern subcontinent
column4: including Odisha and Bihar
column5: alongside other regions surrounding the northwestern Himalayan corridor. Bengali is the seventh most-spoken language in the world
column6: and has a strong literary tradition; the national anthems of India and Bangladesh are written in Bengali. Assamese and Odia are the official languages of Assam and Odisha
column7: respectively. The Eastern Indo-Aryan languages descend from Magadhan Apabhraṃśa[24] and ultimately from Magadhi Prakrit.[25][26][24] Eastern Indo-Aryan languages display many morphosyntactic features similar to those of Munda languages
column8: while western Indo-Aryan languages do not. It is suggested that "proto-Munda" languages may have once dominated the eastern Indo-Gangetic Plain
column9: and were then absorbed by Indo-Aryan languages at an early date as Indo-Aryan spread east.[27][28]

column1: • Sadanic: Kurmali (Panchpargania);
• Tharu:[29] Kochila Tharu

column2: Kuswaric:[30] Danwar

column1: • Halbic: Halbi
• Odia: Baleswari
• Bengali-Gauda: Bengali (Bangali
• Assamese-Kamarupic: Assamese (Kamrupi

Southern Zone

[edit]
Marathi-Konkani languages are ultimately descended from Maharashtri Prakrit
column2: whereas Insular Indo-Aryan languages are descended from Elu Prakrit and possess several characteristics that markedly distinguish them from most of their mainland Indo-Aryan counterparts. Insular Indo-Aryan languages (of Sri Lanka and Maldives) started developing independently and diverging from the continental Indo-Aryan languages from around 5th century BCE.[17]

column1: • Sinhala: Vedda
• Maldivian: Dhivehi

Unclassified

[edit]
The following languages are otherwise unclassified within Indo-Aryan:
• Chinali–Lahul Lohar:[31] Chinali

History

[edit]

Indian subcontinent

[edit]
See also: Linguistic history of India
Dates indicate only a rough time frame.
• early Old Indo-Aryan: includes Vedic Sanskrit (c. 1500 to 500 BCE)
• late Old Indo-Aryan: Epic Sanskrit
column2: Classical Sanskrit (c. 200 CE to 1300 CE)

column1: • Mitanni Indo-Aryan (c. 1400 BCE)
• Middle Indo-Aryan or Prakrits (c. 300 BCE to 1500 CE)
• early Buddhist texts (c. 6th or 5th century BCE)
• middle Middle Indo-Aryan: e.g. Dramatic Prakrits
column2: Elu (c. 200 BCE to 700 CE)

column1: • late Middle Indo-Aryan: e.g. Abahattha (c. 700 CE to 1500 CE)
• Early Modern Indo-Aryan (Late Medieval India): e.g. early Dakhini and emergence of the Dehlavi dialect
Early Indo-European migrations from the Pontic–Caspian steppe
Main article: Proto-Indo-Aryan language

Proto-Indo-Aryan (or sometimes Proto-Indic[a]) is the reconstructed proto-language of the Indo-Aryan languages. It is intended to reconstruct the language of the pre-Vedic Indo-Aryans. Proto-Indo-Aryan is meant to be the predecessor of Old Indo-Aryan (1500–300 BCE)
column2: which is directly attested as Vedic and Mitanni-Aryan. Despite the great archaicity of Vedic
column4: the other Indo-Aryan languages preserve a small number of conservative features lost in Vedic.

column1:
Mitanni-Aryan hypothesis

[edit]
Main article: Indo-Aryan superstrate in Mitanni

column3: and other terminology of the Late Bronze Age Mitanni civilization of Upper Mesopotamia exhibit an Indo-Aryan superstrate. While what few written records left by the Mittani are either in Hurrian (which appears to have been the predominant language of their kingdom) or Akkadian (the main diplomatic language of the Late Bronze Age Near East)
column4: these apparently Indo-Aryan names suggest that an Indo-Aryan elite imposed itself over the Hurrians in the course of the Indo-Aryan expansion. If these traces are Indo-Aryan
column5: they would be the earliest known direct evidence of Indo-Aryan
column6: and would increase the precision in dating the split between the Indo-Aryan and Iranian languages (as the texts in which the apparent Indicisms occur can be dated with some accuracy).

column1: In a treaty between the Hittites and the Mitanni
column5: and the Ashvins (Nasatya) are invoked. Kikkuli's horse training text includes technical terms such as aika (cf. Sanskrit eka
column17: round in the horse race). The numeral aika "one" is of particular importance because it places the superstrate in the vicinity of Indo-Aryan proper as opposed to Indo-Iranian in general or early Iranian (which has aiva).[32] Another text has babru (babhru
column22: "red"). Their chief festival was the celebration of the solstice (vishuva) which was common in most cultures in the ancient world. The Mitanni warriors were called marya
column23: the term for "warrior" in Sanskrit as well; note mišta-nnu (= miẓḍha

column1: Sanskritic interpretations of Mitanni royal names render Artashumara (artaššumara) as Ṛtasmara "who thinks of Ṛta" (Mayrhofer II 780)
column3: biriiašṷa) as Prītāśva "whose horse is dear" (Mayrhofer II 182)
column4: Priyamazda (priiamazda) as Priyamedha "whose wisdom is dear" (Mayrhofer II 189
column6: Citrarata as Citraratha "whose chariot is shining" (Mayrhofer I 553)
column7: Indaruda/Endaruta as Indrota "helped by Indra" (Mayrhofer I 134)
column8: Shativaza (šattiṷaza) as Sātivāja "winning the race price" (Mayrhofer II 540
column10: Šubandhu as Subandhu "having good relatives" (a name in Palestine
column16: Vedic Tvastar "whose chariot is vehement" (Mayrhofer

column1:
Old Indo-Aryan

[edit]
The earliest evidence of the group is from Vedic Sanskrit
column2: that is used in the ancient preserved texts of the Indian subcontinent
column3: the foundational canon of the Hindu synthesis known as the Vedas. The Indo-Aryan superstrate in Mitanni is of similar age to the language of the Rigveda
column4: but the only evidence of it is a few proper names and specialized loanwords.[33]

column1: While Old Indo-Aryan is the earliest stage of the Indo-Aryan branch
column2: from which all known languages of the later stages Middle and New Indo-Aryan are derived
column3: some documented Middle Indo-Aryan variants cannot fully be derived from the documented form of Old Indo-Aryan (on which Vedic and Classical Sanskrit are based)
column4: but betray features that must go back to other undocumented dialects of Old Indo-Aryan.[34]
elaborated') developed as the prestige language of culture
column8: etc. Sanskrit of the later Vedic texts is comparable to Classical Sanskrit
column9: but is largely mutually unintelligible with Vedic Sanskrit.[35]

column1:
Middle Indo-Aryan (Prakrits)

[edit]

column2: vernacular dialects (Prakrits) continued to evolve. The oldest attested Prakrits are the Buddhist and Jain canonical languages Pali and Ardhamagadhi Prakrit
column3: respectively. Inscriptions in Ashokan Prakrit were also part of this early Middle Indo-Aryan stage.

column2: the Prakrits had diversified into various Middle Indo-Aryan languages. Apabhraṃśa is the conventional cover term for transitional dialects connecting late Middle Indo-Aryan with early Modern Indo-Aryan
column3: spanning roughly the 6th to 13th centuries. Some of these dialects showed considerable literary production; the Śravakacāra of Devasena (dated to the 930s) is now considered to be the first Hindi book.

column1: The next major milestone occurred with the Muslim conquests in the Indian subcontinent in the 13th–16th centuries. Under the flourishing Turco-Mongol Mughal Empire
column2: Persian became very influential as the language of prestige of the Islamic courts due to adoption of the foreign language by the Mughal emperors.

column1: The largest languages that formed from Apabhraṃśa were Bengali

New Indo-Aryan

[edit]

Medieval Hindustani
[edit]
Main article: Hindustani language
See also: History of Hindustani
In the Central Zone Hindi-speaking areas
column2: for a long time the prestige dialect was Braj Bhasha
column3: but this was replaced in the 13th century by Dehlavi-based Hindustani. Hindustani was strongly influenced by Persian
column4: with these and later Sanskrit influence leading to the emergence of Modern Standard Hindi and Modern Standard Urdu as registers of the Hindustani language.[36][37] This state of affairs continued until the division of the British Indian Empire in 1947
column5: when Hindi became the official language in India and Urdu became official in Pakistan. Despite the different script the fundamental grammar remains identical
column6: the difference is more sociolinguistic than purely linguistic.[38][39][40] Today it is widely understood/spoken as a second or third language throughout South Asia[41] and one of the most widely known languages in the world in terms of number of speakers.

column1:
Outside the Indian subcontinent

[edit]

Domari

[edit]
Main article: Domari language

Domari is an Indo-Aryan language spoken by older Dom people scattered across the Middle East. The language is reported to be spoken as far north as Azerbaijan and as far south as central Sudan.[42]: 1  Based on the systematicity of sound changes
column2: linguists have concluded that the ethnonyms Domari and Romani derive from the Indo-Aryan word ḍom.[43]

column1:
Lomavren

[edit]
Main article: Lomavren language
Lomavren is a nearly extinct mixed language
column2: spoken by the Lom people
column3: that arose from language contact between a language related to Romani and Domari[44] and the Armenian language.

column1:
Parya

[edit]
Main article: Parya language
Parya is spoken in Tajikistan and Uzbekistan by the descendants of migrants from the Indian subcontinent. The language retains many features similar to Punjabi and the Western Hindi dialects
column2: while also bearing some influence from Tajik Persian.[45]

column1:
Romani

[edit]
Main article: Romani language
The Romani language is usually included in the Western Indo-Aryan languages.[46] Romani varieties
column2: which are mainly spoken throughout Europe
column3: are noted for their relatively conservative nature; maintaining the Middle Indo-Aryan present-tense person concord markers
column4: alongside consonantal endings for nominal case. Indeed
column5: these features are no longer evident in most other modern Central Indo-Aryan languages. Moreover
column6: Romani shares an innovative pattern of past-tense person
column8: such as Kashmiri and Shina. This is believed to be further indication that proto-Romani speakers were originally situated in central regions of the subcontinent
column9: before migrating to northwestern regions. However
column10: there are no known historical sources regarding the development of the Romani language specifically within India.

column1: Research conducted by nineteenth-century scholars Pott (1845) and Miklosich (1882–1888) demonstrated that the Romani language is most aptly designated as a New Indo-Aryan language (NIA)
column2: as opposed to Middle Indo-Aryan (MIA); establishing that proto-Romani speakers could not have left India significantly earlier than AD 1000.

column1: The principal argument favouring a migration during or after the transition period to NIA is the loss of the old system of nominal case
column2: coupled with its reduction to a two-way nominative-oblique case system. A secondary argument concerns the system of gender differentiation
column3: due to the fact that Romani has only two genders (masculine and feminine). Middle Indo-Aryan languages (named MIA) generally employed three genders (masculine
column5: and some modern Indo-Aryan languages retain this aspect today.

column1: It is suggested that loss of the neuter gender did not occur until the transition to NIA. During this process
column2: most of the neuter nouns became masculine
column3: while several became feminine. For example
column4: the neuter aggi "fire" in Prakrit morphed into the feminine āg in Hindi
column5: and jag in Romani. The parallels in grammatical gender evolution between Romani and other NIA languages have additionally been cited as indications that the forerunner of Romani remained on the Indian subcontinent until a later period
column6: possibly as late as the tenth century.

column1:
Sindhic migrations

[edit]

column3: and Luwati represent offshoots of the Sindhic subfamily of Indo-Aryan that have established themselves in the Persian Gulf region
column4: perhaps through sea-based migrations. These are of a later origin than the Rom and Dom migrations which represent a different part of Indo-Aryan as well.

column1:
Indentured labourer migrations

[edit]
The use by the British East India Company of indentured labourers led to the transplanting of Indo-Aryan languages around the world
column2: leading to locally influenced lects that diverged from the source language
column3: such as Fiji Hindi and Caribbean Hindustani.

column1:
Phonology

[edit]

Consonants

[edit]

Stop positions

[edit]
The normative system of New Indo-Aryan stops consists of five places of articulation: labial
column6: which is the same as that of Sanskrit. The "retroflex" position may involve retroflexion
column7: or curling the tongue to make the contact with the underside of the tip
column8: or merely retraction. The point of contact may be alveolar or postalveolar
column9: and the distinctive quality may arise more from the shaping than from the position of the tongue. Palatal stops have affricated release and are traditionally included as involving a distinctive tongue position (blade in contact with hard palate). Widely transcribed as [tʃ]
column10: Masica (1991:94) claims [cʃ] to be a more accurate rendering.

column2: some languages and dialects have alveolar affricates [ts] instead of palatal
column3: though some among them retain [tʃ] in certain positions: before front vowels (esp. /i/)
column4: before /j/
column5: or when geminated. Alveolar as an additional point of articulation occurs in Marathi and Konkani where dialect mixture and others factors upset the aforementioned complementation to produce minimal environments
column6: in some West Pahari dialects through internal developments (*t̪ɾ
column7: t̪ > /tʃ/)
column8: and in Kashmiri. The addition of a retroflex affricate to this in some Dardic languages maxes out the number of stop positions at seven (barring borrowed /q/)
column9: while a reduction to the inventory involves *ts > /s/
column10: which has happened in Assamese
column12: Sinhala (though there have been other sources of a secondary /ts/)

column1: Further reductions in the number of stop articulations are in Assamese and Romani
column2: which have lost the characteristic dental/retroflex contrast
column4: which may lose its labial and velar articulations through spirantisation in many positions (> [f
column5: x]). [47] /q x ɣ f/ are restricted to Perso-Arabic loanwords in most IA languages but they occur natively in Khowar.[48] According to Masica (1991) some dialects of Pashayi have a /θ/ which is unusual for IA languages. Domari which is spoken in the Middle East and had high contact with Middle Eastern languages has /q ħ ʕ ʔ/ and emphatic consonants from loanwords.

column1:
Nasals

[edit]
Sanskrit was noted as having five nasal-stop articulations corresponding to its oral stops
column2: and among modern languages and dialects Dogri
column8: and Sindhi have been analysed as having this full complement of phonemic nasals /m/ /n/ /ɳ/ /ɲ/ /ŋ/
column9: with the last two generally as the result of the loss of the stop from a homorganic nasal + stop cluster ([ɲj] > [ɲ] and [ŋɡ] > [ŋ])
column10: though there are other sources as well.[50]

column1: In languages that lack phonemic nasals at some places of articulation
column2: they can still occur allophonically from place assimilation in a nasal + stop culture
column3: e.g. Hindi /nɡ/ > [ŋɡ].

column1: /m/
/n/
/ɳ/
/ɲ/
/ŋ/

column4: [b] Kalami

column1:
Aspiration and breathy-voice

[edit]
Most Indo-Aryan languages have contrastive aspiration (/ʈ/ ~ /ʈʰ/)
column2: and some retain historical breathy voice on voiced consonants (/ɖ/ ~ /ɖʱ/). Sometimes both phenomena are analysed as a single aspiration contrast. The places and manners of articulation which allow contrastive aspiration vary by language; e.g. Sindhi permits phonemic /mʱ/
column3: but the phonemic status of this sound in Hindi is uncertain
column4: and many "Dardic" languages lack aspirated retroflex sibilants despite having unaspirated equivalents.[51]

column2: the contrast has often been replaced with tone.

column1:
Regional developments

[edit]
Some of these are mentioned in Masica (1991:104–105).
• Implosives: Languages in the Sindhic subfamily
column2: as well as Saraiki
column4: and some dialects of Gujarati have developed implosive consonants from historical intervocalic geminates and word-initial stops. Sindhi has a full implosive series except for the dental implosive: /ɠ ʄ ᶑ ɓ/. It has been claimed that Wadiyari Koli has the dental implosive too. Other languages have less complete implosive series
column5: e.g. Kacchi has just /ᶑ ɓ/.

column1: • Prenasalized stops: Sinhala and Maldivian (Dhivehi) have a series of prenasalized stops covering all places except for palatal: /ᵐb ⁿd ᶯɖ ᵑɡ/.
• Palatalization: Kashmiri (natively) and some Romani dialects (from contact with Slavic languages) have contrastive palatalisation.
• Voiceless lateral In Gawarbati
column3: partly Bashkarik and some Shina dialects have /ɬ/ from clusters of tr kr or sometimes pr; dr gr and br merged with /l/ in these languages.

column1: • Lateral affricates: Bhadarwahi has an unusual series of lateral retroflex affricates (/ʈ͡ꞎ ɖ͡ɭ ɖ͡ɭʱ/ derived from historical /Cɾ/ clusters.

Vowels

[edit]
Vowel typologies are varied across Indo-Aryan due to diachronic mergers and (in some cases) splits
column2: as well as different accounts by linguists for even the widely-spoken languages. Vowel systems per Masica (1991:108–113) are listed below. Many languages also have phonemic nasal vowels.

column1: /iː i eː e ɨː ɨ əː ə aː a ɔː ɔ oː o uː u/
/ɪ iː ʊ uː e eː ə~ɐ əː o oː æ~ɛ a aː ɔ/
/iː i eː e æː æ aː a ə oː o uː u/

Sylheti language is one of the few tonal Indo-Aryan languages
column2: others being Punjabi and a few Dardic languages. The vowels of Sylheti language listed below.[52]

Register

[edit]

column2: the literary register is often more archaic and utilises a different lexicon (Sanskrit or Perso-Arabic) than spoken vernacular. One example is Bengali's high literary form
column4: as opposed to the more modern Calita bhāṣā (Cholito-bhasha).[55] This distinction approaches diglossia.

column1:
Language and dialect

[edit]

column2: the choice between the appellations "language" and "dialect" is a difficult one
column3: and any distinction made using these terms is obscured by their ambiguity. In one general colloquial sense
column4: a language is a "developed" dialect: one that is standardised
column5: has a written tradition and enjoys social prestige. As there are degrees of development
column6: the boundary between a language and a dialect thus defined is not clear-cut
column7: and there is a large middle ground where assignment is contestable. There is a second meaning of these terms
column8: in which the distinction is drawn on the basis of linguistic similarity. Though seemingly a "proper" linguistics sense of the terms
column9: it is still problematic: methods that have been proposed for quantifying difference (for example
column10: based on mutual intelligibility) have not been seriously applied in practice; and any relationship established in this framework is relative.[56]
